title: 109_s1260
content: The Act titled "Common Sense Indian Gambling Reform Act of 2005" requires consultation with state, local, and tribal governments. Section 20 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (25 U.S.C. 2719) is amended to specify conditions for Indian tribes in Oklahoma without reservations to establish gaming facilities on certain lands. Section 20 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to specify exceptions for Indian lands in Oklahoma without reservations to establish gaming facilities after consultation with relevant authorities within 60 miles of the land. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to allow Indian tribes in Oklahoma without reservations to establish gaming facilities on land that is in their best interest and does not have a negative economic impact on nearby entities within 60 miles. The concurrence of the affected state is required for the Secretary's determination to be valid. The Common Sense Indian Gambling Reform Act of 2005 specifies that the land for gaming facilities must have a primary nexus to the Indian tribe's location within a state, as determined by the Secretary. This provision does not apply to land where a gaming facility is already in operation before the Act's enactment. The Act specifies that a geographic, social, and historical nexus to land of an Indian tribe is required for gaming facilities, which includes land owned by or held in trust for the tribe within designated geographical areas. The Act requires a geographic, social, and historical connection to land for Indian tribe gaming facilities, within designated geographical areas where the tribe historically resided. The Act requires Indian tribes to conduct gaming activities on contiguous parcels of Indian lands within their recognized reservations in states other than Oklahoma. SEC. 3. TRIBAL GAMING ORDINANCES. Section 11 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to include provisions for class II gaming on Indian lands before or after the date of enactment. The Indian tribe requested that the land be taken into trust for the purpose of conducting class II gaming activities. Amendments were made to Section 11 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act regarding gaming on Indian lands. Amendments were made to Section 11 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act to allow gaming activities on Indian lands, including lands taken into trust for the benefit of Indian tribes. Amendments to Section 11 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act allow Indian tribes to conduct class III gaming activities on land taken into trust for their benefit. The definition of 'State' in this subsection includes the Governor and legislative body of the State. Amendments to the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act allow Indian tribes to conduct class III gaming activities on trust land. The definition of 'State' includes the Governor and legislative body. SEC. 4 addresses investigation and approval. Amendments to the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act grant powers to the Chairman and Commission regarding gaming activities. The Chairman can approve or disapprove the involvement of top stakeholders in gaming activities, while the Commission must identify these stakeholders. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act amendments empower the Chairman and Commission to oversee gaming activities. The Chairman can approve or disapprove the involvement of top stakeholders, while the Commission must identify and conduct background investigations on these stakeholders. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act amendments authorize the Commission to conduct background investigations on key individuals involved in tribal gaming enterprises on an ongoing basis. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act amendments increase Commission funding from $8,000,000 to $16,000,000 for background investigations on key individuals in tribal gaming enterprises. SEC. 5. CHANGING USE OF INDIAN LAND. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to require Indian tribes to submit an environmental impact statement and obtain the Secretary's consent before using Indian lands for gaming purposes. The Act and its amendments will not impact any existing compacts or agreements related to gaming regulated under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act.
